title.value: Learning Hybrid Interpretable Models: Theory, Taxonomy, and Methods
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as given in the provided text.
title.quote: Learning Hybrid Interpretable Models: Theory, Taxonomy, and Methods

extractions.description: The paper investigates hybrid models combining interpretable and complex black-box components to address the accuracy-transparency trade-off in machine learning. It explores the theory, taxonomy, and methods of such models, and introduces the HybridCORELS algorithm.

type.justification: The paper implements and evaluates new methods (HybridCORELS) in comparison with existing ones using various datasets.
type.quote: We empirically show, using the proposed HybridCORELSPre algorithm, that the Pre-Black-Box paradigm is suitable for learning accurate hybrid models with transparency constraints.

name.justification: The main focus of the paper is on hybrid models which aim to balance transparency and performance, key issues in interpretable machine learning.
name.quote: This is why we believe Hybrid Models are a very interesting research direction in the quest for interpretable machine learning.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses how hybrid models balance interpretability and performance.
name.quote: We define the system’s transparency as the ratio of samples that are sent to the interpretable part.

name.justification: The entire paper is dedicated to the theory and methods behind hybrid models that combine interpretable models with black-box models.
name.quote: A hybrid model involves the cooperation of an interpretable model and a complex black box.

name.justification: The transparency of machine learning models—specifically hybrid models—is a central theme in the paper.
name.quote: We finally show empirically that HybridCORELS is competitive with existing hybrid models while being partly transparent.

name.justification: The paper presents HybridCORELS as the primary model and contribution.
name.quote: Thirdly, we implement the two paradigms in a single method: HybridCORELS, which extends the CORELS algorithm to hybrid modeling.

is_contributed.justification: HybridCORELS is introduced as a novel contribution in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Thirdly, we implement the two paradigms in a single method: HybridCORELS, which extends the CORELS algorithm to hybrid modeling.

is_executed.justification: The paper discusses the implementation and empirical evaluation of HybridCORELS.
is_executed.quote: We empirically show, using the proposed HybridCORELSPre algorithm, that the Pre-Black-Box paradigm is suitable for learning accurate hybrid models.

is_compared.justification: HybridCORELS is compared to existing hybrid models like HyRS and CRL.
is_compared.quote: We empirically compare both HybridCORELSPre and HybridCORELSPost with state-of-the-art methods for learning hybrid models.

referenced_paper_title.justification: HybridCORELS is a new contribution and not cited from another paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Thirdly, we implement the two paradigms in a single method: HybridCORELS, which extends the CORELS algorithm to hybrid modeling.

name.justification: HybridCORELS extends the CORELS algorithm for hybrid modeling.
name.quote: Our method, called HybridCORELSPost is the first to provide optimality guarantees and explicit control of the model transparency.

is_contributed.justification: CORELS is cited as a basis for the new HybridCORELS, but it is not a new contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We modify a state-of-the-art algorithm for learning optimal sparse rule lists, named CORELS.

is_executed.justification: CORELS itself is not executed; it is extended into HybridCORELS, which is executed.
is_executed.quote: We modify a state-of-the-art algorithm for learning optimal sparse rule lists, named CORELS.

is_compared.justification: The original CORELS algorithm is not a hybrid model and thus not directly compared to other hybrid models.
is_compared.quote: We modify a state-of-the-art algorithm for learning optimal sparse rule lists, named CORELS.

referenced_paper_title.value: Learning Certifiably Optimal Rule Lists for Categorical Data
referenced_paper_title.justification: The CORELS algorithm is referenced from the work by Angelino et al.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Angelino et al. (2017) proposed CORELS, a branch-and-bound algorithm.

name.justification: The paper uses the COMPAS dataset for empirical evaluation.
name.quote: The COMPAS dataset contains 6,150 records from criminal offenders in the Broward County of Florida collected from 2013 and 2014.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset description mentions a source, but not a specific paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The COMPAS dataset contains 6,150 records from criminal offenders in the Broward County of Florida collected from 2013 and 2014.

name.justification: The UCI Adult Income dataset is used for evaluating the hybrid models.
name.quote: The UCI Adult Income dataset stores demographic attributes of 48,842 individuals from the 1994 U.S. census.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The UCI Adult Income dataset is referenced from the UCI machine learning repository.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The UCI Adult Income dataset (Dua and Graff, 2017)

name.justification: The ACS Employment dataset is used for evaluating the hybrid models.
name.quote: The ACS Employment dataset is an extension of the UCI Adult Income dataset that includes more recent Census data (2014-2018).

referenced_paper_title.value: Retiring Adult: New Datasets for Fair Machine Learning
referenced_paper_title.justification: The ACS Employment dataset is referenced from the work by Ding et al.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The ACS Employment dataset (Ding et al., 2021)

name.justification: The paper uses Scikit-learn classifiers like RandomForest and AdaBoost.
name.quote: In all experiments we used the following Scikit-learn classifiers: RandomForestClassifier, AdaBoostClassifier, GradientBoostingClassifier.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Scikit-learn is referenced from Pedregosa et al.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In all experiments we used the following Scikit-learn (Pedregosa et al., 2011) classifiers.
